COMP1511.name: Programming Fundamentals
COMP1511.desc: An introduction to problem-solving via programming, which aims to have students develop proficiency in using a high level programming language.

ELEC1111.name: Electrical and Telecommunications Engineering
ELEC1111.desc: An introduction to the art and science of Electrical Engineering and Telecommunications, and the systems approach to engineering design.

ELEC2141.name: Digital Circuit Design
ELEC2141.desc: Introduction to modern digital logic design, combinational logic, switch logic and basic gates, Boolean algebra, two-level logic, regular logic structures, multi-level networks and transformations, programmable logic devices, time response.

ENGG1000.name: Introduction to Engineering Design and Innovation
ENGG1000.desc: In this course, students will experience first hand one of the major things that engineers do: designing and building creative solutions to problems.

equivalents.name: Introduction to Engineering Design and Innovation

PHYS1131.name: Higher Physics 1A
PHYS1131.desc: This course provides an introduction to Physics.

PHYS1231.name: Higher Physics 1B
PHYS1231.desc: This is the second of the two introductory courses in Physics.

MATH1131.name: Mathematics 1A
MATH1131.desc: Complex numbers, vectors and vector geometry, linear equations, matrices and matrix algebra, determinants.

MATH1141.name: Higher Mathematics 1A
MATH1141.desc: As for MATH1131 but in greater depth.

MATH1231.name: Mathematics 1B
MATH1231.desc: Vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

MATH1241.name: Higher Mathematics 1B
MATH1241.desc: Vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

ELEC2117.name: Electrical Systems Design
ELEC2117.desc: This second year design course complements the design thread in the School, drawing from knowledge gained in first year courses on electronic circuits, programming, and digital circuits.

ELEC2133.name: Analogue Electronics
ELEC2133.desc: Device physics of diodes, BJTs and MOSFETs.

ELEC2134.name: Circuits and Signals
ELEC2134.desc: Circuit elements - energy storage and dynamics.

ELEC2142.name: Embedded Systems Design
ELEC2142.desc: An introduction to programmer model of computer organisation using assembly and machine language.

equivalents.name: Project in Photovoltaics and Renewable Energy 2

MATH2069.name: Mathematics 2A
MATH2069.desc: Several Variable Calculus:Vectors, differential calculus of curves in R3 and  surfaces, Taylor series for functions of two variables, critical points, local maxima and minima.

MATH2099.name: Mathematics 2B
MATH2099.desc: Linear algebra: Vector spaces, linear transformations, change of basis, inner products, orthogonalization, least squares approximation, QR factorization, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization, Jordan forms, matrix exponentials and applications to systems of differential equations, other applications of linear algebra.

ELEC3104.name: Digital Signal Processing
ELEC3104.desc: Processing and analysis of continuous (analogue) and discrete-time (digital) signals.

ELEC3105.name: Electrical Energy
ELEC3105.desc: Electrical energy supply systems: transmission and distribution systems; Basic aspects of both the supply and utilization of electrical energy, with some emphasis on contemporary aspects of energy utilization including modern developments, energy efficiency and environmental aspects.

ELEC3114.name: Control Systems
ELEC3114.desc: Recognition of what a control system is, and the distinction between simple and complex control systems.

ELEC3115.name: Electromagnetic Engineering
ELEC3115.desc: Review of vector calculus, Electric Fields: Coulomb's and Gauss's laws and Maxwell's equations, Electric potential, Laplace's and Poisson's  equations; Magnetic Fields: Biot-Savart law, Vector potential and  Ampere's law and Maxwell's equations;Application of Gauss's law;  Solution of Poisson's and Laplace's equations for electric field;  Boundary value problems and method of images; Dielectric materials, capacitance, electrostatic energy and forces, losses; Field and current density, conductance; Application of Ampere's law; Magnetic materials, inductance, coupling in magnetic circuits; Magnetic energy and forces.

ELEC3117.name: Electrical Engineering Design
ELEC3117.desc: Design Project Management: Introduction to scheduling, costing, marketing, standards, patents, quality, safety, (electronic) manufacturing methods, engineering innovation, Report Writing and Oral Presentations.

ELEC4122.name: Strategic Leadership and Ethics
ELEC4122.desc: Theories of leadership; leadership of teams.

ELEC4123.name: Electrical Design Proficiency
ELEC4123.desc: The course involves four competency components, as follows:Electronic Circuit Design: Devices, amplifiers, tuned circuits, opamp circuits, etc.

ELEC4951.name: Research Thesis A
ELEC4951.desc: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

ELEC4952.name: Research Thesis B
ELEC4952.desc: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

ELEC4953.name: Research Thesis C
ELEC4953.desc: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

ELEC9451.name: Masters Project A
ELEC9451.desc: The project provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

ELEC9452.name: Masters Project B
ELEC9452.desc: The project provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

ELEC9453.name: Masters Project C
ELEC9453.desc: The project provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

GSOE9210.name: Engineering Decision Structures
GSOE9210.desc: In this course stduents will learn how to apply a range of analytical decision-making methodologies to help them be better decision-makers.

GSOE9445.name: Entrepreneurial Engineering
GSOE9445.desc: Course introduction: the entrepreneurial revolution; the entrepreneurial process; opportunities recognizing and screening; entrepreneur and the internet; entrepreneur, manager and team; obtaining venture and growth capital; resource requirements; business plan; introduction to entrepreneurial finance; rapid growth and troubled times; ethics and the entrepreneur; harvesting the wealth.

GSOE9820.name: Engineering Project Management
GSOE9820.desc: This course will introduce to you the fundamental principles of project management in an engineering context, enabling you to become a successful project manager.

GSOE9830.name: Economic Decision Analysis in Engineering
GSOE9830.desc: Project initiation and development, review of practical decision-making problems and relevant techniques, benefit/cost analysis, time value of money, Nominal and effective interest rate, calculation involving multiple interest formulae, internal rate of return, payback period method, comparisons of alternative investments, depreciation methods, income tax consideration, inflation, replacement analysis, sensitivity analysis, life-cycle costing, economic analysis of projects.

COMP3211.name: Computer Architecture
COMP3211.desc: Study the architecture & organisation of modern processors, and influences upon these, with emphasis on pipelined RISC machines; gain understanding of the design of the memory subsystem, I/O, and system level interconnect; become proficient in the use of tools such as VHDL and SimpleScalar for the description, simulation, and verification of architectural designs; complete a series of assignments leading to the design, implementation, validatation and assessment of a RISC system.

ELEC2146.name: Electrical Engineering Modelling and Simulation
ELEC2146.desc: Electrical Engineering Modelling and Simulation surveys the basic techniques required for computer modelling of a range of electrical engineering systems.

ELEC3106.name: Electronics
ELEC3106.desc: Non-ideal effects in electronic circuits and systems: Noise; device noise, external noise, CMRR, PSRR, mixed A/D.

MATH3101.name: Computational Mathematics for Science and Engineering
MATH3101.desc: Partial differential equations (PDEs) provide a natural mathematical description for many phenomena of interest in science and engineering.

MATH3121.name: Mathematical Methods and Partial Differential Equations
MATH3121.desc: This course builds on MATH2120 Mathematical Methods for Differential Equations in that it is concerned with ways of solving the (usually partial) differential equations that arise mainly in physical, biological and engineering applications.

MATH3161.name: Optimization
MATH3161.desc: Optimization problems, in which one wants to find the values of variables to maximize or minimize an objective function subject to constraints on which variables are allowed, are common throughout the physical and biological sciences, economics, finance and engineering.

MATH3201.name: Dynamical Systems and Chaos
MATH3201.desc: A dynamical system is any system whose state changes as a function of time.

MATH3261.name: Fluids, Oceans and Climate
MATH3261.desc: The mathematical modelling and theory of problems arising in the flow of fluids, the oceans and the global climate; Cartesian tensors, kinematics, mass conservation, vorticity, Navier-Stokes equation; topics from inviscid and viscous fluid flow, gas dynamics, sound waves, water waves.

MATH3411.name: Information, Codes and Ciphers
MATH3411.desc: Discrete communication channels: information theory, compresssion and error control coding, cryptography.

TELE3113.name: Analogue and Digital Communications
TELE3113.desc: Telecommunication Fundamentals: Free space propagation characteristics, phasors, fourier transform, spectrum analysis, random signals.

TELE3118.name: Network Technologies
TELE3118.desc: Network architectures in terms of topology, role (client/server, peer-to-peer), and layered specification.

TELE3119.name: Trusted Networks
TELE3119.desc: CRYPTOGRAPHY: (i) Symmetric Encryption and Message Confidentiality, (ii) Public-Key Cryptography and Message Authentication, (iii) Key Distribution, (iv) Mathematical Principles of Cryptography.

ELEC4445.name: Entrepreneurial Engineering
ELEC4445.desc: Course introduction: the entrepreneurial revolution; the entrepreneurial process; opportunities recognizing and screening; entrepreneur and the internet; entrepreneur, manager and team; obtaining venture and growth capital; resource requirements; business plan; introduction to entrepreneurial finance; rapid growth and troubled times; eithics and the entrepreneur; harvesting the wealth.

ELEC4601.name: Digital and Embedded Systems Design
ELEC4601.desc: Topics include; introduction to custom digital processors including DSP hardware, high-speed digital design techniques, modern chip design methodologies, hardware and software co-design, advanced programming paradigms including state machines and concurrent processes, real-time programming and operating systems.

ELEC4602.name: Microelectronic Design and Technology
ELEC4602.desc: Basic IC processing technology: lithography, oxidation, diffusion, implantation, film deposition, etching, metalisation.

ELEC4611.name: Power System Equipment
ELEC4611.desc: Power transformers, instrument transformers, rotating machines, cables and overhead lines, circuit interrupters (fuses, surge arresters, circuit breakers).

ELEC4612.name: Power System Analysis
ELEC4612.desc: An overview of modern power systems.

ELEC4614.name: Power Electronics
ELEC4614.desc: Power semiconductor switching devices and their limitations; Switching characteristics, protection and limitations of various types of power semiconductor switches; Elementary concepts in power electronics; Application of power electronic converters in energy conversion, utility applications and power supplies and utilizations; Diode rectifier circuits, multi-pulse rectifiers, input and output waveform characterization, filter design.

ELEC4621.name: Advanced Digital Signal Processing
ELEC4621.desc: FIR Lattice filters, All-pole IIR Lattice filters and their implementation; Fixed Point or finite word length implementations and effects; Random Processes, Auto-correlation,cross-correlation, and power spectrum estimation techniques;   Leastsquare filter design, Adaptive filters, Wiener filters,  adaptive noise cancellation; Linear prediction, statistical and deterministic formulation.

ELEC4622.name: Multimedia Signal Processing
ELEC4622.desc: Signal acquisition, sampling and interpolation for signals in 1, 2 and 3 dimensions.

ELEC4623.name: Biomedical Instrumentation, Measurement and Design
ELEC4623.desc: Introduction to Biomedical Instrumentation and Physiological Measurement.

ELEC4631.name: Continuous - Time Control System Design
ELEC4631.desc: Overview of systems and control engineering with emphasis on modern and post-modern developments.

ELEC4632.name: Computer Control Systems
ELEC4632.desc: Examples of digital control systems, differences and similarities between digital and analog control systems, discrete-time systems, stability analysis, observability and Controllability, state space models, digital PID controllers, pole placement design, digital control systems characteristics, nonlinear discrete-time systems, optimal control design methods, discrete Kalman filter, identification, case studies.

ELEC4633.name: Real-Time Engineering
ELEC4633.desc: Real-time operating systems and processes: Concurrent processes.

PHTN4661.name: Optical Circuits and Fibres
PHTN4661.desc: Types and applications of optical fibers; ray analysis of multimode fibres; characteristics of single-mode fibres including experiments; losses and dispersion in fibres; fibre fabrication; cabling and handling fibres.

PHTN4662.name: Photonic Networks
PHTN4662.desc: All-optical & hybrid networks, topologies; WDM; optical switching & routing, SONET; dispersion management, BER & sources of noise, power budgets; phase modulation effects & nonlinear scattering in optical links; safety, regulations & standards.

TELE4642.name: Network Performance
TELE4642.desc: This course aims to develop an understanding of the tools and technologies for understanding and improving the performance of communication networks such as the Internet.

TELE4651.name: Wireless Communication Technologies
TELE4651.desc: Wireless Communications Channels: time-variant multipath fading, Doppler shift, fade rate, shadowing effect, time selective channel, frequency selective channel, the effects of fading on wireless transmission, performance analysis.

TELE4652.name: Mobile and Satellite Communications Systems
TELE4652.desc: Introduction to Mobile Communications: historical development of mobile telephony.

TELE4653.name: Digital Modulation and Coding
TELE4653.desc: Communication concepts: Fourier transforms, random signals, Transmitter and receiver filters, matched filter, Nyquist criterion.

ELEC9701.name: Mixed Signal Microelectronic Design
ELEC9701.desc: The aim of the course is to enable the student to design advanced analogue, digital and mixed signal microelectronic circuits and to enable self-guided continuing learning in the advancing field of microelectronics.

ELEC9702.name: Radio Frequency Integrated Circuit Design
ELEC9702.desc: The objective of this course is to provide postgraduate students with an advanced understanding of designing RF integrated circuits in state-of-the-art CMOS technology with the ultimate purpose of integrating the entire transceiver on an IC chip.

ELEC9703.name: Microsystems Design and Technology
ELEC9703.desc: Interdisciplinary overview of MST (MicroElectroMechanical Systems - MEMS).

ELEC9705.name: Quantum Devices
ELEC9705.desc: The course on Quantum Devices provides a rigorous but accessible introduction to the working principles and the uncommon properties of nano-engineered electronic devices, whose dynamics no longer obeys the laws of classical physics.

ELEC9711.name: Power Electronics for Renewable and Distributed Generation
ELEC9711.desc: The topics to be covered in this course will include: Grid integration of electrical power from renewable sources; Current and voltage control; Advanced topics in DC-DC converters, inverters, AC-DC converters and AC-AC converters for use in utility interfacing; resonant converters for DC-DC conversion; dynamic representation of DC-DC converters, control loops design; converter circuit and system modelling using LTSpice or other platforms, device selection and their modeling, thermal design, gate drive circuit design, magnetic core and other component selection and design, and case studies of converter system designs.

ELEC9712.name: High Voltage Systems
ELEC9712.desc: High voltage engineering and technology form an important area in power engineering.

ELEC9713.name: Industrial and Commercial Power Systems
ELEC9713.desc: The aim of the course is to provide practical knowledge on the design and operation of electrical distribution systems in large commercial buildings or industrial sites.

ELEC9714.name: Electricity Industry Planning and Economics
ELEC9714.desc: The nature of the electricity & gas industries; climate change and the electricity industry; objectives & options for restructuring; insights from electricity pricing theory; wholesale electricity market design; Australia's restructured electricity industry; National Electricity Market design & performance; the role of electricity networks in a restructured electricity industry including market representation, network pricing and network regulation; ancillary services; design & implementation of retail electricity markets; electricity industry regulation.

ELEC9715.name: Electricity Industry Operation and Control
ELEC9715.desc: Induction to the evolving electricity industry drivers of restructuring, technological developments and environmental concerns, and their impact on power system operation.

ELEC9716.name: Electrical Safety
ELEC9716.desc: This course covers the very broad and important area of electrical safety in domestic and industrial installations.

ELEC9721.name: Digital Signal Processing Theory and Applications
ELEC9721.desc: Least squares digital filter design and realisation, finite word length effects, random processes, adaptive filters, linear prediction, multi-rate signal processing, time-frequency analysis, sub-band transforms and wavelets.

ELEC9722.name: Digital Image Processing
ELEC9722.desc: The fundamentals of digital image processing with topics selected from the following: image models and physical imaging systems; visual perception; rendering systems; linear filtering; linear transforms; mathematical morphology; compression; tomographic image reconstruction; inverse problems in imaging; image enhancement; edge detection; feature extraction; and geometric diffusion.

ELEC9723.name: Speech Processing
ELEC9723.desc: Fundamentals of speech production, speech analysis: pitch and period extraction, formant estimation, voiced - unvoiced decision.

ELEC9725.name: Satellite Navigation: Systems, Signals & Receivers
ELEC9725.desc: This course introduces the electronic and signal processing aspects of Global Positioning System (GPS) and other satellite navigation systems e.

ELEC9731.name: Robust and Linear Control Systems
ELEC9731.desc: Rationale for the study of linear methods.

ELEC9732.name: Analysis and Design of Non-linear Control
ELEC9732.desc: The course is taught in two halves.

ELEC9733.name: Real Computing and Control
ELEC9733.desc: Examines the implementation of modern control techniques and associated instrumentation using distributed computers.

GMAT9200.name: Principles of GPS Positioning
GMAT9200.desc: This course will introduce the student to reference coordinate systems and time systems, satellite orbital motion, signal propagation and satellite tracking observables.

GSOE9758.name: Network Systems Architecture
GSOE9758.desc: Pre-requisites: Background in data networks, e.

TELE9751.name: Switching Systems Architecture
TELE9751.desc: This course provides detailed knowledge of the design of equipment and protocols used to build communication networks such as the Internet.

TELE9752.name: Network Operations and Control
TELE9752.desc: This course introduces the principles, techniques, and tools used for the management of modern communication networks such as the Internet.

TELE9753.name: Advanced Wireless Communications
TELE9753.desc: This course provides advanced knowledge of wideband wireless communication techniques to enable the students to design advanced wireless communication systems.

TELE9754.name: Coding and Information Theory
TELE9754.desc: This course provides advanced knowledge of error control coding technique and theories of information transmission mainly at the physical layer.

TELE9755.name: Microwave Circuits, Theory and Techniques
TELE9755.desc: The general flow of the course is Applications, Systems, Components.

TELE9756.name: Advanced Networking
TELE9756.desc: This course provides advanced knowledge of telecommunication networks currently being deployed or likely to be deployed in the future.

TELE9757.name: Quantum Communications
TELE9757.desc: This course is aimed at Graduate Engineers and Physicists wishing to understand the exciting new world of Quantum Communications.

BIOMDS.name: Biomedical Engineering (Dual Mode)
BIOMDS.desc:
The stream is designed for students who are completing the Masters of Biomedical Engineering program as part of a dual-award program with a Bachelor of Engineering (Honours) in the following specialisations only:
Bioinformatics EngineeringChemical EngineeringComputer EngineeringElectrical EngineeringMaterials Science and EngineeringMechanical EngineeringMechatronic EngineeringSoftware EngineeringTelecommunications
Students are required to complete 72 units of credit, 48 of which must be at postgraduate level and a minimum of 48 units must be from the courses listed below.

BINFAH.name: Bioinformatics Engineering
BINFAH.desc: Bioinformatics Engineering is studied as a major stream in the BE (Hons).

CEICAH.name: Chemical Engineering
CEICAH.desc: Chemical Engineering involves researching, developing and improving properties of products we use every day through the selection of raw materials, the design of chemical processes, and improving the conditions for production.

COMPBH.name: Computer Engineering
COMPBH.desc: Computer Engineering encompasses the structured and integrated design of the hardware and software components of computerised systems.

ELECAH.name: Electrical Engineering
ELECAH.desc: The School of Electrical Engineering & Telecommunications offers a wide range of undergraduate and postgraduate study in all areas of the professions of Electrical Engineering and Telecommunications.

MECHAH.name: Mechanical Engineering
MECHAH.desc: The Mechanical Engineering stream provides a versatile, comprehensive coverage of areas involving the conception and design of machinery and mechanical plant, the supervision of its construction, operation and maintenance, the planning and supervision of large engineering projects, and general engineering management.

MTRNAH.name: Mechatronic Engineering
MTRNAH.desc: The Mechatronic Engineering stream provides the student with the ability to acquire a hybrid range of skills based on mechanics, electronics and computing.

SENGAH.name: Software Engineering
SENGAH.desc: Software Engineering is an Engineering profession concerned with the processes, methods, and tools for the design and development of high quality, reliable software systems.

TELEAH.name: Telecommunications
TELEAH.desc: Telecommunications engineering is the most rapidly developing and dynamic field of Engineering.

ENGG1300.name: Engineering Mechanics
ENGG1300.desc: This is the  foundational mechanics course for students in Aerospace, Civil, Environmental, Manufacturing, Mechanical, Mechatronics and Mining Engineering, with content as follows: Revision of vectors, resultants and components, moments; The free body diagram; Equilibrium of planar rigid objects; Equilibrium of systems of co-planar multi-force members and planar trusses; Frames and Machines; Springs; Friction; Mass centre, centroids, distributed forces; Internal forces in beams; Introduction to 3-dimensional statics; Plane particle kinematics, including curvilinear and relative motion; Plane particle kinetics, including equations of motion, work-energy-power, friction, impulse-momentum, impact; Kinetics of systems of particles; Introduction to plane kinematics of rigid bodies, types of rigid body motion (translation, rotation about a fixed axis); Mass moment of inertia, parallel axis theorem, moment of inertia for various shapes, Introduction to plane kinetics of rigid bodies, rigid body in plane motion, equations of motion, work-energy for a rigid body.

PHYS1121.name: Physics 1A
PHYS1121.desc: This course provides an introduction to Physics.

COMP1911.name: Computing 1A
COMP1911.desc: This course introduces students to the basics of programming.

other: PREREQUISITE: ENROLMENT IN A NON-CSE MAJOR (NO BINF, COMP, OR SENG)

ENGG1811.name: Computing for Engineers
ENGG1811.desc: The objective of this course is for students to acquire computing skills for solving problems in engineering.

other: PREREQUISITE: ENROLMENT IN A NON-CSE MAJOR (NO BINF, COMP, OR SENG)

DESN2000.name: Engineering Design and Professional Practice
DESN2000.desc: Design is one of the critical foundations of engineering and a main component in creating value.

equivalents.name: Project in Photovoltaics and Renewable Energy 2

ENGG2400.name: Mechanics of Solids 1
ENGG2400.desc: This course provides an introduction to the fundamentals to the mechanics of solids.

equivalents.name: Mechanics of Solids for Civil Engineers

ENGG2500.name: Fluid Mechanics for Engineers
ENGG2500.desc: The objective of ENGG2500 is to introduce engineering students to the principles of fluid mechanics.

MATH2019.name: Engineering Mathematics 2E
MATH2019.desc: Partial differentiation and applications, vector algebra, double integrals, ordinary differential equations, introduction to vector field theory, extrema of functions of 2 variables, matrices and their applications, Laplace transforms, Fourier series, partial differential equations and their solution for selected physical problems.

MATH2089.name: Numerical Methods and Statistics
MATH2089.desc: This course gives an introduction to numerical methods and statistics essential in a wide range of engineering disciplines.

MMAN2130.name: Design and Manufacturing
MMAN2130.desc: This course introduces basic aspects of design and manufacturing, process selection, manufacturing processes, material selection based on material and physical properties and the use of computers in the design process.

MMAN2300.name: Engineering Mechanics 2
MMAN2300.desc: This course covers the practical application of engineering mechanics and mechanical vibrations.

MMAN2700.name: Thermodynamics
MMAN2700.desc: Thermodynamic concepts, systems, property, state, path, process.

AERO3110.name: Aerospace Design 1
AERO3110.desc: This course aims to provide students with a grounding in aerospace design, in terms of both structural design and systems design.

AERO3410.name: Aerospace Structures
AERO3410.desc: This course covers introductory and intermediate topics related to analysis and design of airframes:Aerospace Materials and their PropertiesLightweight Materials - Alloys and CompositesTensors - Stress, Strain, InvariantsFailure PredictionMaterial Degradation - Fatigue, Corrosion, WearAnalysis of Composite MaterialsClassical Airframe AnalysisAirframe LoadsStressed Skin Design PhilosophyRole of Airframe ComponentsThin-walled ApproximationStructural IdealisationAnalysis of Indeterminate TrussesBending, Shear and Torsion of Complex BeamsDetailed Stressing - Joints and Cut-outsStructural Instability and AeroelasticityBuckling of Columns and PlatesStiffened Panel Analysis and DesignAeroelasticity - Divergence, Control Reversal and Flutter.

AERO3630.name: Aerodynamics
AERO3630.desc: The overall aim of this course is to introduce students to the art and science of aerodynamics: how fluid motion generates the forces and moments on air vehicles required for flight.

MMAN3000.name: Professional Engineering and Communication
MMAN3000.desc: Professional Engineering and Communication is a subject designed to expose and involve students in a wide variety of topics and tasks which will be of lasting use going into Industrial Training, the final year thesis, and beyond that, a career in engineering.

MMAN3200.name: Linear Systems and Control
MMAN3200.desc: Models of physical systems: differential equations for physical systems including mechanical, electrical, hydraulic, thermal and pneumatic systems; linearisation.

AERO4110.name: Aerospace Design 2
AERO4110.desc: This course is a capstone aerospace design project.

AERO4620.name: Dynamics of Aerospace Vehicles, Systems and Avionics

MMAN4010.name: Thesis A
MMAN4010.desc: This course is the first of two parts and is undertaken before MMAN4020 Thesis B.

MMAN4020.name: Thesis B
MMAN4020.desc: To be taken in the last semester required for the completion of all requirements for the award of the degree, i.

MMAN4951.name: Research Thesis A
MMAN4951.desc: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

MMAN4952.name: Research Thesis B
MMAN4952.desc: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

MMAN4953.name: Research Thesis C
MMAN4953.desc: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

AERO9500.name: Space Systems Architectures and Orbits
AERO9500.desc: This course paints the overall picture of what a satellite system is.

AERO9610.name: The Space Segment
AERO9610.desc: This course gives the students a basis in the design issues involved in the engineering of the space segment in order to enable to fulfil the mission.

AERO9660.name: Advanced Aerospace Propulsion
AERO9660.desc:
This course aims to enable you to:
gain a deeper appreciation of gas turbine operation and to make high-level predictions of gas turbine behavior in various flight scenarios.

MECH4305.name: Fundamental and Advanced Vibration Analysis
MECH4305.desc: The following assumed knowledge is expected for postgraduate students undertaking this course: MATH2019 and (MMAN2300).

MECH4320.name: Engineering Mechanics 3
MECH4320.desc: The following assumed knowledge is expected for postgraduate students undertaking this course: MATH2019 and (MMAN2300).

MECH4620.name: Computational Fluid Dynamics
MECH4620.desc: This course will focus on the terminology, principles and methods of CFD – Computational Fluid Dynamics.

MECH4900.name: Mechanics of Fracture and Fatigue
MECH4900.desc:
Topics
Theories of fracture; failure modes.

MECH9420.name: Composite Materials and Mechanics
MECH9420.desc:
Using a unified and integrated approach, this course will give you a solid grounding in:
 The properties of composite materials; Processing and manufacturing methods; Micromechanics and lamination theory;The analysis and manufacture of light weight composite structures; The design of a composite structures; Test methods to confirm mechanical properties.

MMAN4200.name: Additive Manufacturing
MMAN4200.desc: Additive manufacturing, also known as 3D printing, is an emerging advanced manufacturing technique which has enjoyed a rapid growth in recent years.

MMAN4400.name: Engineering Management
MMAN4400.desc: Manufacturing operations and competitiveness, concurrent product and process design, manufacturing processes and technologies, global supply chain, E-manufacturing, Just-in-time and lean manufacturing, enterprise resource planning, production and materials planning, statistical process control techniques, quality and project management.

MMAN4410.name: Finite Element Methods
MMAN4410.desc: The following assumed knowledge is expected for postgraduate students undertaking this course: MMAN2400.

COMP3141.name: Software System Design and Implementation
COMP3141.desc: This course will present rigorous and formal methods for the design and implementation phases of software system development.

ENGG3060.name: Maker Games
ENGG3060.desc: Under the guidance of academic mentors and industry mentors, this course provides a vehicle for guided but independent group project work on an industry-provided brief.

MANF4100.name: Design and Analysis of Product-Process Systems
MANF4100.desc: The following assumed knowledge is expected for postgraduate students undertaking this course: MANF3100 and MANF3510.

MANF4430.name: Reliability and Maintenance Engineering
MANF4430.desc: The course will introduce statistics, mathematics and associated techniques for analyzing an industrial process for the purpose of maintaining and improving it.

MANF4611.name: Process Modelling and Simulation
MANF4611.desc: The following assumed knowledge is expected for postgraduate students undertaking this course: MATH2089.

MANF6860.name: Strategic Manufacturing Management
MANF6860.desc: This course focuses on the links between both  manufacturing strategies as well as operational performance  and  effective supply chain strategies for companies that operate globally with emphasis on how to plan and integrate supply chain components into a coordinated system.

MANF9400.name: Industrial Management
MANF9400.desc: Evolution of management thought, the planning process; nature of managerial decision making, organisational structures; managing organisational change, motivation, performance, satisfaction, interpersonal and organisational communication, use of management information systems.

MANF9420.name: Operations and Supply Chain Management in Engineering
MANF9420.desc: Design, control, operation and management of supply chain systems; supply chain strategies; supply chain drivers and metrics, network design in supply chain; global supply chain networks; demand forecasting and aggregate planning in supply chain, economies of scale in supply chain; managing uncertainty in supply chain; transportation in a supply chain; sourcing decision in a supply chain, procurement and outsourcing strategies, price and revenue management in supply chain; information technology in a supply chain; sustainability in supply chain.

MANF9472.name: Production Planning and Control
MANF9472.desc: Industry dynamics; Porters Model; bases for competition and implications for Production Planning and Control.

MECH4100.name: Mechanical Design 2
MECH4100.desc: The following assumed knowledge is expected for postgraduate students undertaking this course: MECH3110 and MMAN2300.

MECH4880.name: Refrigeration and Air Conditioning 1
MECH4880.desc: The following assumed knowledge is expected for postgraduate students undertaking this course: MMAN2600 and MMAN2700.

MECH9325.name: Fundamentals of Acoustics & Noise
MECH9325.desc: Development of the acoustic plane wave equation, introduction of concepts of acoustic impedance, characteristic impedance, acoustic energy density, acoustic intensity and acoustic power.

MECH9650.name: Micro and Biofluidics
MECH9650.desc: This course introduces the fundamentals of biofluids.

MECH9660.name: Biofluid Dynamics and Systems
MECH9660.desc: Engineers are increasingly working alongside clinical colleagues to solve complex health related problems.

MECH9720.name: Solar Thermal Energy Design
MECH9720.desc: The following assumed knowledge is expected for postgraduate students undertaking this course: MMAN2600 and MMAN2700.

MECH9761.name: Automobile Engine Technology
MECH9761.desc: This course introduces the fundamentals of how the design and operation of automobile engines affect the performance and emissions.

MTRN4030.name: Optimisation Methods for Engineering Systems
MTRN4030.desc: This course will enable students to acquire an understanding of optimization concepts in engineering system designs and the application of optimization algorithms in mechanical, manufacturing, and mechatronic systems.

MTRN9400.name: Control of Robotic Systems
MTRN9400.desc: This course provides a mathematical introduction to the mechanics and control of robotic systems including robot manipulators, mobile ground robots and quadrotors.

SOLA5052.name: Biomass
SOLA5052.desc: This course will introduce a range of biomass energy sources, including forestry, wastes and crops, as well as various technologies for their conversion into useful fuels or power.

SOLA5053.name: Wind Energy Converters
SOLA5053.desc: This course will cover the principles of wind energy and wind power, as well as the design and operation of different types of wind energy converters.

SOLA5056.name: Sustainable Energy for Developing Countries
SOLA5056.desc: This course covers many of the technical and non-technical issues relating to introducing photovoltaics and renewable energy systems and technology in developing countries.

SOLA5057.name: Energy Efficiency
SOLA5057.desc: If Australia and the world are to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases, both renewable energy and more efficient use of that energy will be required.

BABS1201.name: Molecules, Cells and Genes
BABS1201.desc: The course is concerned with the basic characteristics of all life.

BIOM1010.name: Engineering in Medicine and Biology
BIOM1010.desc: This course introduces the field of biomedical engineering where the principles of engineering are used to solve problems in medicine and biology.

BIOS1301.name: Ecology, Sustainability and Environmental Science
BIOS1301.desc: This course provides an introduction to ecology, sustainability and environmental science, introducing a range of biological topics and how scientists approach these topics to solve problems.

CEIC1000.name: Sustainable Product Engineering and Design
CEIC1000.desc: This course is an introduction to process/product engineering and design in which the technical, environmental, social, economic and marketing aspects involved in the manufacture of products ranging from everyday consumer goods (food, pharmaceuticals, etc.

CHEM1011.name: Chemistry 1A: Atoms, Molecules and Energy
CHEM1011.desc: This course builds on an elementary knowledge of chemistry (equivalent to one year of high school chemistry, such as Year 11 chemistry, or CHEM1001 at UNSW) to explore the quantum mechanical structure of atoms leading to an understanding of the periodic trends in the properties of the elements.

equivalents.name: Chemistry A: Atoms, Molecules, and Energy
Higher Chemistry 1A: Atoms, Molecules and Energy
Higher Chemistry 1A (Medicinal): Atoms, Molecules and Energy

CHEM1021.name: Chemistry 1B: Elements, Compounds and Life
CHEM1021.desc: CHEM1021 deals with a range of fundamental concepts that can be used to explain various phenomena in chemistry, biology and material science.

equivalents.name: Chemistry B: Elements, Compounds and Life

CHEM1031.name: Higher Chemistry 1A: Atoms, Molecules and Energy
CHEM1031.desc: This course builds on an elementary knowledge of chemistry (equivalent to two years of high school chemistry, such as Year 12 chemistry, or CHEM1001 at UNSW) to explore the quantum mechanical structure of atoms leading to an understanding of the periodic trends in the properties of the elements.

other: PREREQUISITE: MUST BE ENROLLED IN A PROGRAM WITH THE OPTION OF A CHEM MAJOR

equivalents.name: Higher Chemistry 1A (Medicinal): Atoms, Molecules and Energy
Chemistry A: Atoms, Molecules, and Energy

CHEM1041.name: Higher Chemistry 1B: Elements, Compounds and Life
CHEM1041.desc: CHEM1041 deals with a range of fundamental concepts that can be used to explain various phenomena in chemistry, biology and material science.

CHEM1811.name: Engineering Chemistry 1A
CHEM1811.desc: This course builds on an introductory knowledge of chemistry (equivalent to two years of high school chemistry, such as Year 11 and 12 chemistry) to explore the engineering aspects of chemistry.

CHEM1821.name: Engineering Chemistry 1B
CHEM1821.desc: This course further develops the introduction to the engineering aspects of chemistry started in CHEM1811.

COMP1521.name: Computer Systems Fundamentals
COMP1521.desc: This course provides a programmer's view on how a computer system executes programs, manipulates data and communicates.

COMP1531.name: Software Engineering Fundamentals
COMP1531.desc: This course provides an introduction to software engineering principles: basic software lifecycle concepts, modern development methodologies, conceptual modeling and how these activities relate to programming.

CVEN1701.name: Environmental Principles and Systems
CVEN1701.desc: This is an introductory course in techniques to analyse the environmental impact of corporations and economies in regions, using operations research, environmental material accounting and environmental risk assessment.

ENGG1100.name: Grand Challenges for Engineering
ENGG1100.desc: These special projects are designed for highly motivated undergraduates seeking the opportunity to integrate specific curricular and co-curricular components into their undergraduate program, to provide them with superior preparation and experience in a project area.

ENGG1200.name: Undergraduate Special Projects
ENGG1200.desc: These special projects are designed for highly motivated undergraduates seeking the opportunity to integrate specific curricular and co-curricular components into their undergraduate program, to provide them with superior preparation and experience in a project area.

ENGG1400.name: Engineering Infrastructure Systems
ENGG1400.desc: A course in optimization and modelling for first year engineering students who desire a higher capability in the application of the modelling of engineering systems, and seek to acquire a set of optimization tools that can be applied to various engineering applications.

GEOS1111.name: Fundamentals of Geology
GEOS1111.desc: This course provides a sound basis in Geology to those wishing to pursue professional careers as geologists, mining and petroleum engineers and environmental earth scientists.

GMAT1110.name: Surveying and Geospatial Engineering
GMAT1110.desc: Surveying and Geospatial Engineering deals with the science of determining relative positions of features above, on or below the surface of the Earth for a range of mapping, engineering and construction operations.

MATH1081.name: Discrete Mathematics
MATH1081.desc: Role of proof in mathematics, logical reasoning and implication, different types of proofs.

MATS1101.name: Engineering Materials and Chemistry
MATS1101.desc: Materials Strand: Structure-property relationships of the main types of engineering materials (metals, ceramics, polymers and composites).

MATS1110.name: Introduction to Materials for Engineering Applications
MATS1110.desc: This course introduces Engineering students to the field of Materials Science and Engineering.

MINE1010.name: Mineral Resources Engineering
MINE1010.desc: This course includes an overview of the Australian minerals industry and the presence and development of mineral resources in Australia; the role of the mining engineer and career path options; awareness of major mineral types and distribution in Australia; basic mining concepts and systems, operations, equipment & services; an introduction to risk management and general issues of safety, health and wellbeing, including important issues for the safety of persons visiting or working at mining operations in remote or bushland areas.

PSYC1001.name: Psychology 1A
PSYC1001.desc: This course introduces key conceptual, theoretical and methodological underpinnings of psychology as a basic science, with emphasis on the social bases of behaviour.

SOLA1070.name: Sustainable Energy
SOLA1070.desc: Students will be introduced to the central concepts of energy and sustainability with a particular focus on sustainable energy systems through their use of the multiplayer PlayEnergy online simulation/game.

PHYS1111.name: Fundamentals of Physics
PHYS1111.desc: This is an introductory level course in physics for students from all disciplines.

BINF2010.name: Introduction to Bioinformatics
BINF2010.desc: The course surveys the major areas of bioinformatics, exploring the history of bioinformatics in relation to advances in computing hardware and software; the biological problems currently being addressed using bioinformatics; and future applications of bioinformatics.

BIOC2201.name: Principles of Molecular Biology (Advanced)
BIOC2201.desc: Provides an introduction to modern molecular biology and covers the molecular mechanisms of gene expression and fundamental aspects of recombinant DNA technology.

COMP2511.name: Object-Oriented Design & Programming
COMP2511.desc: This course aims to introduce students to the principles of object-oriented design and to fundamental techniques in object-oriented programming.

COMP2521.name: Data Structures and Algorithms
COMP2521.desc: The goal of this course is to deepen students' understanding of data structures and algorithms and how these can be employed effectively in the design of software systems.

MATH2801.name: Theory of Statistics
MATH2801.desc: Probability, random variables, standard distributions, bivariate distributions, transformations, central limit theorem, sampling distributions, point estimation, interval estimation, hypothesis testing.

MATH2901.name: Higher Theory of Statistics
MATH2901.desc: As for MATH2801 but in greater depth:This course provides an introduction to the theoretical underpinning of statistics; it covers fundamental results from probability and distribution theory and shows how to apply the theory to the analysis of data.

BABS2202.name: Molecular Cell Biology 1
BABS2202.desc: Cells are not only the basic building blocks of all organisms they are also the source of the vast diversity that characterizes life on earth.

BABS2204.name: Genetics
BABS2204.desc: Genetics is the study of inheritance and is an exciting and rapidly expanding discipline with applications in medicine, biotechnology, agriculture and many other fields.

BABS2264.name: Genetics (Advanced Level)
BABS2264.desc: Genetics is the study of inheritance and is an exciting and rapidly expanding discipline with applications in medicine, biotechnology, agriculture and many other fields.

BIOC2101.name: Principles of Biochemistry (Advanced)
BIOC2101.desc: BIOC2101 introduces modern biochemistry, covers fundamental aspects of the structure-function relationships of proteins and an overall coverage of intermediary metabolism.

MICR2011.name: Microbiology 1
MICR2011.desc: Microscopic life pervades every aspect of our lives, influencing our health, diet, and environment.

BABS3121.name: Molecular Biology of Nucleic Acids
BABS3121.desc: The syllabus comprises a detailed analysis of gene structure and function which includes: structure and properties of polynucleotides such as DNA and RNA; structure of chromatin; mechanisms and regulation of gene replication, transcription and translation, DNA repair and the molecular biology of cancer induction; recombinant DNA technology; nulceic acid sequencing, ecombinant DNA technology, application of genomics and proteomics, microarray analyses; protein production using recombinant DNA systems.

BINF3010.name: Applied Bioinformatics
BINF3010.desc: Bioinformatics (the use of computing methods for the management and analysis of molecular biology data) has become an integral component of biomolecular sciences, especially genomics and proteomics.

BINF6112.name: Computational Biology Engineering Design Workshop
BINF6112.desc: Through a practical software project and targeted lectures this course examines various issues in the design and implementation of software systems for the analysis of large complex biological datasets and the application of mathematical and statistical methods to problems in modern life science.

COMP4920.name: Management and Ethics
COMP4920.desc: This course will develop a framework on which management and ethical issues can be developed.

COMP4951.name: Research Thesis A
COMP4951.desc: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

COMP4952.name: Research Thesis B
COMP4952.desc: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

COMP4953.name: Research Thesis C
COMP4953.desc: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

CEIC2000.name: Material and Energy Systems
CEIC2000.desc: In this course students will learn sufficient thermodynamics and problem solution strategies to be able to apply thermodynamic concepts with material and energy balances to chemical process problems involving several unit operations and involving chemical reactions.

CEIC2002.name: Heat and Mass Transfer
CEIC2002.desc: In this course, the principles of transport phenomena introduced previously in fluid flow are extended to heat and mass transport.

CEIC2005.name: Chemical Reaction Engineering
CEIC2005.desc: Applied physical chemistry, kinetics and reaction engineering.

CEIC2007.name: Chemical Engineering Lab A
CEIC2007.desc: This course is designed to consolidate your understanding of basic principles in chemical engineering and develop your skills in planning, experimental technique including data acquisition, and analysis.

MATH2018.name: Engineering Mathematics 2D
MATH2018.desc: Partial differentiation and applications, vector algebra, double integrals, ordinary differential equations, introduction to vector field theory, extrema of functions of 2 variables, matrices and their applications, Laplace transforms, Fourier series, partial differential equations and their solution for selected physical problems.

CEIC3000.name: Process Modelling and Analysis
CEIC3000.desc: The previous course name was Chem Eng Fundamentals 3.

CEIC3001.name: Advanced Thermodynamics and Separation
CEIC3001.desc: In this course, the student will learn to apply his or her fundamental knowledge of transport phenomena with concepts in thermodynamics to develop models for industrial separation operations, in conjunction with additional study of thermodynamics of phase equilibria for multi-component systems.

CEIC3004.name: Process Equipment Design
CEIC3004.desc: This course teaches the student about selection and design of chemical process equipment and the use of simulation software as an aid to equipment design.

CEIC3005.name: Process Plant Design
CEIC3005.desc: The previous course name was Chem Eng Design 3B.

CEIC3006.name: Process Dynamics and Control
CEIC3006.desc: The previous course name was Chem Eng Design 3C.

CEIC3007.name: Chemical Engineering Lab B
CEIC3007.desc: This course is designed to develop and extend your skills in designing and executing experimental investigation of chemical engineering problems.

CEIC4000.name: Environment and Sustainability
CEIC4000.desc: This course aims to develop a profound understanding of concepts of environmental and social responsibility and professional ethics, both in the wider sense and as they relate to the specific context of chemical engineering and industrial chemistry.

CEIC4001.name: Process Design Project
CEIC4001.desc: Please Note: Pre-requisites: at least 144 UOC taken in Industrial Chemistry or Chemical Engineering programs.

CEIC4951.name: Research Thesis A
CEIC4951.desc: Research Thesis is an inquiry-based learning course that provides an opportunity for students to bring together engineering principles learned through academic study.

CEIC4952.name: Research Thesis B
CEIC4952.desc: Research Thesis s an inquiry-based learning course that provides an opportunity for students to bring together engineering principles learned through academic study.

CEIC4953.name: Research Thesis C
CEIC4953.desc: Research Thesis is an inquiry-based learning course that provides an opportunity for students to bring together engineering principles learned through academic study.

CEIC6004.name: Advanced Polymers
CEIC6004.desc: We will explore exciting macromolecular chemistry in a range of selected cutting edge research fields.

CEIC6711.name: Complex Fluids Microstructure and Rheology
CEIC6711.desc: The link between molecules and the macroscopic properties we measure depends on the microscale and mesoscale structures the molecules form in complex fluids like emulsions, foams, aerosols, and particle dispersions.

CEIC6789.name: Data-driven Decision Making in Chemical Engineering and Food Science
CEIC6789.desc: The recent surge in the volume of data collected owing to technological advances provides opportunities to improve processes and take better decisions across various industries.

CEIC8102.name: Advanced Process Control
CEIC8102.desc: Concepts of linear Multi-Input Multi-Output (MIMO) systems, state-space representation of process systems, linear spaces and linear operators, controllability and observability analysis, Lyapunov stability analysis, stability of interconnected systems, linear optimal control, frequency-domain analysis and controller synthesis for MIMO process systems.

CHEN6701.name: Advanced Reaction Engineering
CHEN6701.desc: This subject is geared towards senior undergraduate students with interests in the design and optimization of process reaction vessels in the chemicals/petrochemicals, biological/food as well as materials/minerals processing industries.

CHEN6703.name: Advanced Particle Systems Engineering
CHEN6703.desc: The course covers lectures and demonstrations on: Particle characterisation and preparation using the latest techniques, floc characterisation and its relevance in separation techniques.

CHEN6706.name: Advanced Transport Phenomena
CHEN6706.desc: This course presents a unified and advanced approach to the study of transport phenomena, which unifies the topics of mass, momentum and heat transport.

CEIC6005.name: Fuel and Energy
CEIC6005.desc: Current energy resources and alternatives for the future.

CEIC6712.name: Pharmaceutical Design and Engineering
CEIC6712.desc: Students will learn how to design, develop and evaluate pharmaceutical and nutraceutical agents in line with research and industry methods, where chemical engineers, nutritionists and medical researchers work together to transform raw materials and small molecular agents to valuable pharma products.

CEIC8204.name: Topics in Business Management in Chemical Engineering
CEIC8204.desc: The aims of this course are to introduce issues which affect business  decisions encountered by management in the chemical industry.

CEIC8330.name: Process Engineering in the Petroleum Industry

CEIC8341.name: Membrane Processes
CEIC8341.desc: Please note that CEIC2001 (Fluid and particle mechanics) and CEIC2002 (heat and mass transfer) are prerequisites to enrol in CEIC8341.

CHEM2041.name: Analytical Chemistry: Essential Methods
CHEM2041.desc: This course teaches the essential methods in analytical chemistry applicable to chemists, biologists, and most other disciplines of science.

ENGG3001.name: Fundamentals of Humanitarian Engineering
ENGG3001.desc: This course enables engineers to analyse and design infrastructure and appropriate technology to support the well-being and welfare of individuals and communities in disadvantaged circumstances.

FOOD3010.name: Food Preservation
FOOD3010.desc: The basis of food science is presented in a series of lectures covering traditional and novel methods of preserving foods for distribution and storage.

FOOD8450.name: Advanced Food Engineering
FOOD8450.desc: This course consists of lectures and discussion groups covering advanced aspects of modern food processing and preservation.

GSOE9111.name: Energy Storage
GSOE9111.desc: This course course provides training on energy issues covering techniques for energy storage, their capabilities, limitations and issues with their use.

POLY3000.name: Polymer Science
POLY3000.desc: Polymer and their manufacture play a very important part in our daily lives and the technologies that we use.

CEIC4954.name: Research Thesis Extension
CEIC4954.desc: This course will provide students with an opportunity to go extend their thesis project by exploring their research problem in more breadth &/or depth.

ENGG4060.name: Student Initiated Project
ENGG4060.desc: This fourth year elective course allows students to deliver a project, of their design, that engages the strength of cross-disciplinary student teams.

ENGG4102.name: Humanitarian Engineering Project
ENGG4102.desc: This course provides students with the opportunity to undertake a design project related to Humanitarian Engineering.

CHEM2021.name: Organic Chemistry: Mechanisms and Biomolecules
CHEM2021.desc: Organic molecules are at the heart of the chemistry of life and industry.

CHEM2031.name: Inorganic Chemistry: The Elements
CHEM2031.desc: This course provides a general introduction to both theoretical and practical aspects of advanced inorganic chemistry.

CHEM3021.name: Organic Chemistry: Modern Synthetic Strategies
CHEM3021.desc: The need for new functional molecules is greater than ever, with ever-growing demand for new therapeutics and materials for the future.

CEIC4007.name: Product Design Project Thesis A
CEIC4007.desc: Design and creative development is the engine of growth for economies and industry product portfolios.

CEIC4008.name: Product Design Project Thesis B
CEIC4008.desc: Design and creative development is the engine of growth for economies and industry product portfolios.

CEIC8105.name: Advanced Polymer Science and Research
CEIC8105.desc: This course will explore exciting macomolecular chemistry in a range of selected cutting edge research fields.

ELEC3111.name: Distributed Energy Generation
ELEC3111.desc: Distributed energy generation is developing into a significant market in the generation, distribution and utilisation of electrical energy.

ELEC3145.name: Real Time Instrumentation
ELEC3145.desc: Real Time Instrumentation aims to equip students with the necessary and additional computing and hardware skills to be able to work with, and design real time computer systems which are connected as instrumentation and control devices to other electrical and mechanical circuits.

ELEC3705.name: Fundamentals of Quantum Engineering
ELEC3705.desc: The progress of nanotechnology allows the fabrication of devices whose physical dimensions are approaching the atomic scale.

ELEC4605.name: Quantum Devices and Computers
ELEC4605.desc: Quantum Engineering is concerned with the design and production of devices that exploit the laws of Quantum Mechanics, unlocking novel functionalities and improved performance.

ELEC4617.name: Power System Protection
ELEC4617.desc: This course is ideally suited to electrical engineering students planning to pursue a career in Power Engineering.

MECH3110.name: Mechanical Design 1
MECH3110.desc: This course will continue the development of a systematic approach to problem solving and design that commenced in earlier courses.

MECH3610.name: Advanced Thermofluids
MECH3610.desc: Basic concepts of heat transfer, units, dimensions, exchange mechanism.

MMAN3400.name: Mechanics of Solids 2
MMAN3400.desc: Membrane stresses in axisymmetric shells, simple bending, bending of composite and reinforced concrete beams, principal and cross moments of area, unsymmetrical bending, transverse shear stresses in beams, shear centre, column buckling, theory of elasticity: compatibility - equilibrium - constitutive equations - plane stress/strain, st Venant's principal, application of theory of elasticity to axisymmetric problems, torsion of prismatic bars, Prandtl's membrane analogy, torsion of multiply connected thin-walled sections, deflection analysis based on the principle of virtual work, various modes of fracture, crack-tip stresses, stress intensity factor, fracture toughness, crack growth due to fatigue.

CVEN2002.name: Civil and Environmental Engineering Computations
CVEN2002.desc: An introduction to the application of advanced analytical, statistical and numerical techniques to the solution of engineering problems relevant to civil and environmental engineers and surveyors.

CVEN2101.name: Engineering Construction
CVEN2101.desc: An introduction to construction systems and processes.

CVEN2303.name: Structural Analysis and Modelling
CVEN2303.desc: This course introduces students to structural analysis and computer modelling of structures.

CVEN2401.name: Sustainable Transport and Highway Engineering
CVEN2401.desc: The course is presented as 2 strands.

CVEN3101.name: Engineering Operations and Control
CVEN3101.desc: This subject is an introduction to the general principles of the organisation and control of engineering operations.

CVEN3202.name: Soil Mechanics
CVEN3202.desc: An introductory course to fundamentals of soil mechanics.

CVEN3203.name: Applied Geotechnics and Engineering Geology
CVEN3203.desc: This course covers two important areas of geotechnical engineering: geology and applied geotechnics.

CVEN3303.name: Steel Structures
CVEN3303.desc: A course on the design concepts and design of structural elements subject to bending, shear and combined bending and axial compression.

CVEN3304.name: Concrete Structures
CVEN3304.desc: A course on concrete materials and the design of reinforced concrete structural elements subject to bending, shear and combined bending and axial compression.

CVEN3501.name: Water Resources Engineering
CVEN3501.desc: The object of CVEN3501 is to introduce engineering hydrology and its application in water resources management and flood estimation.

CVEN3502.name: Water and Wastewater Engineering
CVEN3502.desc: Assumed Knowledge: MATS1101To introduce students to the principles of public health engineering, water and wastewater treatment, water supply systems, wastewater disposal systems, stormwater systems, biosolids treatment and management, and water quality and contamination indicators.

CVEN4032.name: Higher Honours Thesis A
CVEN4032.desc: This course is the first of two parts and is undertaken prior to CVEN4033 Higher Honours Thesis B.

CVEN4033.name: Higher Honours Thesis B
CVEN4033.desc: This course is the second of two parts and is undertaken after to CVEN4032 Higher Honours Thesis A.

CVEN4050.name: Thesis A
CVEN4050.desc: This course is the first of two parts and is undertaken before CVEN4051 Thesis B, usually in the proceeding semester.

CVEN4051.name: Thesis B
CVEN4051.desc: This course is the second of two parts and is undertaken after the completion of CVEN4050 Thesis A, usually in the proceeding semester.

CVEN4951.name: Research Thesis A
CVEN4951.desc: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

CVEN4952.name: Research Thesis B
CVEN4952.desc: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

CVEN4953.name: Research Thesis C
CVEN4953.desc: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

BENV1012.name: Parametric Design and Digital Fabrication
BENV1012.desc:
This course introduces students to Parametric Design and Digital Fabrication, with emphasis on the direct
relationship between Mathematics and Geometry, and how these two fields constitute the foundations of
any parametric design process.

CODE2170.name: Building Information Modelling
CODE2170.desc: 'The Building Information Modelling course introduces students to identify and explain concepts and methods of Building Information Management (BIM), BIM standards, and BIM in an urban context.

CVEN4002.name: Design Practice A
CVEN4002.desc: This is a project-based course where, working in groups of four, students undertake a major multi-disciplinary design project.

CVEN4003.name: Design Practice B
CVEN4003.desc: A second project-based course where, working in groups of four, students undertake a major multi-disciplinary design project involving discipline areas that are different from those dealt with in CVEN4002 Design Practice A.

CVEN4101.name: Problem Solving for Engineers
CVEN4101.desc: Engineers are characterized as being problem solvers.

CVEN4102.name: Operations and Projects
CVEN4102.desc: Most engineering work fits within what is broadly referred to as operations and projects.

CVEN4103.name: Engineering Contracts
CVEN4103.desc: The majority of engineering work is procured through contracts, within an array of delivery methods.

CVEN4104.name: Sustainability in Construction
CVEN4104.desc: This course will provide fundamental knowledge and hands-on experience for practising sustainability in construction.

CVEN4201.name: Rock and Slope Engineering
CVEN4201.desc: Description of rock mass and discontinuities; rock strength and failure criteria.

CVEN4202.name: Advanced Topics in Geotechnical Engineering
CVEN4202.desc: Topic 1: Application of computer simulation techniques to geotechnical engineering problems.

CVEN4204.name: Ground Improvement and Monitoring Techniques
CVEN4204.desc: Prerequisites: CVEN2201, CVEN3201 or equivalentAssessment of the suitability and design of stabilisation techniques for difficult foundation soils including instrumentation and application observational techniques to geotechnical engineering.

CVEN4300.name: Structures Practicum
CVEN4300.desc: A practical course that involves both advanced analysis and design of an engineered structure to solve a given problem.

CVEN4301.name: Advanced Concrete Structures
CVEN4301.desc: A course on the advanced analysis and design of concrete structures for students looking towards a career in Structural Engineering.

CVEN4308.name: Structural Dynamics
CVEN4308.desc: Fundamentals of structural dynamic analysis for discrete and continuous structures; free and forced vibration of single and multiple degrees of freedom systems; normal modal analysis; transient dynamic analysis by numerical integration; response spectrum; introduction to nonlinear dynamic analysis of structures; wind, earthquake, human-induced vibration and wave loads: definitions and effects on structures; design of structures to resist dynamic loads.

CVEN4309.name: Sustainable Timber Engineering
CVEN4309.desc: Structural and Construction Engineers may be responsible for the design and construction of timber structures; from timber frame housing to high rise engineered timber structures.

CVEN4310.name: Deformation Monitoring Surveys
CVEN4310.desc: This course introduces the concepts, principles and techniques used for deformation monitoring to civil engineering students with an interest in structures or geotechnical.

CVEN4402.name: Transport Systems - Part 1: Network Analysis
CVEN4402.desc: Definition of basic traffic elements, zero flow travel time, capacity, impedance flow relationship.

CVEN4404.name: Fundamentals of Traffic Engineering
CVEN4404.desc: CVEN4404: Fundamentals of Traffic Engineering aims to provide undergraduate students the knowledge and skills necessary to contribute as a practicing Traffic Engineer.

CVEN4405.name: Human Factors in Civil and Transport Engineering
CVEN4405.desc: Human factors is the scientific discipline concerned with the understanding of interactions between humans and other elements of a system.

CVEN4503.name: Groundwater Resource Investigation
CVEN4503.desc: Review of groundwater occurrence in Australia.

CVEN4504.name: Advanced Water and Wastewater Treatment
CVEN4504.desc: Detailed examination of unit processes used in water and wastewater treatment including chemical selection, dosing and mixing, coagulation, flocculation, clarification, filtration and disinfection technology in water treatment and sedimentation and aerobic and anaerobic biological processes in wastewater treatment.

CVEN4701.name: Planning Sustainable Infrastructure
CVEN4701.desc: The course enables engineers to analyse and design sustainable infrastructure to support the needs of regional economies and populations.

CVEN4703.name: Advanced Water Quality Principles
CVEN4703.desc: Fundamental aspects of the chemistry and biology of aquatic environments are reviewed and extended enabling analysis and interpretation of processes occurring in surface and ground waters as well as water and wastewater treatment systems.

CVEN4705.name: Environmental Sustainability - Methods, Tools, Management
CVEN4705.desc: An introduction to sustainable engineering principles and the social, economic and political context in which they have arisen, and in which they are implemented.

CVEN4800.name: Satellite Remote Sensing and Applications
CVEN4800.desc: This course introduces the concepts, principles and techniques used for satellite remote sensing to civil and environmental engineering students.

CVEN9405.name: Urban Transport Planning Practice
CVEN9405.desc: Analytical techniques for urban land use/transport planning practice.

CVEN9415.name: Transport Systems Part 2
CVEN9415.desc: Historical introduction to transport systems and development of various transport modes, road (vehicles, pedestrians, cycles), conveyor, rail, sea and air.

CVEN9612.name: Catchment and Water Resources Modelling
CVEN9612.desc: Processes, generation and modelling of catchment surface runoff quantity and quality; a broad range of surface runoff and water quality models ranging from simple to process based will be considered; selection, calibration, validation and reliability of the various models is presented; water resources data, analysis and modelling including considerations of data sources, errors, time series analysis, stochastic models and extension of hydrological records; stochastic reservoir analysis; optimisation in water resources.

CVEN9620.name: Channels, Rivers and Estuaries
CVEN9620.desc: Models for routing of flows along channels and rivers will be presented including model theory, selection, calibration, validation and reliability; models will include Muskingham, kinematic wave, non-inertial and diffusion and dynamic wave; sediment and pollutant transport water quality methods and models will also be presented including plug-flow and advection-dispersion in both coupled and uncoupled applications; estuarine classification and density structure; tides, water level response, mixing processes and flushing of estuaries; estuarine difference models including hydrodynamic stratification and algal dynamics; random walk and box models; biochemical processes in estuaries.

CVEN9640.name: Coastal Engineering
CVEN9640.desc: Waves in coastal waters including theory, measurement, analysis, forecasting, growth, refraction, diffraction, shoaling and breaking processes; coastal and beach processes including tides, storms, currents, elevated water levels, morphology, sediment transport mechanisms, beach erosion and nourishment, longshore transport, prediction and modelling of shoreline change; wave forces on coastal and ocean structures with application to engineering design of harbours, breakwaters, seawalls, piles, decks, marinas, pipelines and outfalls.

CVEN9809.name: Reinforced Concrete Design
CVEN9809.desc: A dynamic course in the design of reinforced concrete structures to AS3600-2009 and international standards using advanced methods of analysis and design.

CVEN9818.name: Bridge Engineering
CVEN9818.desc: Introduction to bridge engineering; site selection, type selection, bridge hydraulics, design philosophies.

CVEN9822.name: Steel and Composite Structures
CVEN9822.desc: A course on the advanced analysis and design of structural elements for students looking towards a career in Structural Engineering.

CVEN9824.name: Advanced Materials Technology
CVEN9824.desc: Concrete: high performance concrete; new methods of workability measurement; methods of placing-pumping, spraying; mix design methods; special concrete mixes.

CVEN9826.name: Advanced Mechanics of Structures and Materials
CVEN9826.desc: A course in advanced mechanics of structures and materials for higher degree research students, and graduate students that require, or desire, a higher capability in the application of elasticity, plasticity and fracture to analysis of structures and structural materials.

CVEN9881.name: Hazardous Waste Management
CVEN9881.desc: Waste audits and characterisation of hazardous wastes in regions and industries; control of generation and transport of hazardous waste, manifest systems; waste minimisation; on-site treatment methods; integrated off-site treatment facilities; management of residues from treatment facilities; introduction to planning of regional hazardous waste management systems.

CVEN9884.name: Environmental Chemical and Microbial Processes
CVEN9884.desc: Application of chemical principles to aqueous systems; pH and alkalinity, solubility and precipitation, complexation, redox and surface chemistry.

GMAT3220.name: Geospatial Information Systems
GMAT3220.desc: An overview of the components of Geographic Information Systems (GIS).

GSOE9740.name: Industrial Ecology and Sustainable Engineering
GSOE9740.desc: Sustainability means living well within the limits of a finite planet.

CEIC2009.name: Material and Energy Balances in the Chemical Process Industry
CEIC2009.desc: In this course, the relationships between the integration of thermodynamics and mass and energy balance in chemical plants are elucidated.

CVEN2701.name: Water and Atmospheric Chemistry
CVEN2701.desc: This course aims to provide an introduction to water chemistry and atmospheric chemistry, as a foundation for understanding both the natural processes in these environments and the effects of pollution on them.

CVEN3702.name: Solid Wastes and Contaminant Transport
CVEN3702.desc: An introduction to waste management systems, from generation to treatment and disposal; including waste characterisation, waste minimisation, transfer stations, recycling facilities, composting and landfill design.

CVEN4507.name: Advanced Water Engineering
CVEN4507.desc: Advanced closed conduit and open channel hydraulic design, designing for peak pump efficiency, sedimentation engineering, reservoir behaviour and design, estimation of large and extreme floods, advanced topics in hydrological design.

MTRN2500.name: Computing for Mechatronic Engineers
MTRN2500.desc: This course will use Matlab as the primary computational engine for teaching the students to carry out fundamental computations as well as developing simulations through the use of object oriented concepts implemented in Matlab environment.

MTRN3020.name: Modelling and Control of Mechatronic Systems
MTRN3020.desc: This subject teaches the student how to design and develop a control system in discrete-time domain to be used in motion control systems.

MTRN4010.name: Advanced Autonomous Systems
MTRN4010.desc: The following assumed knowledge is expected for postgraduate students undertaking this course: MMAN3200 and MATH2089 and MTRN2500.

MINE2010.name: Mining Project Development
MINE2010.desc: The course covers the life cycle of a mining project including the  various processes involved with the development and operation of a  mining project including exploration & geology, mine planning, mine  operations, minerals beneficiation and marketing.

MINE2810.name: Minerals and Processing
MINE2810.desc: This is an introductory course in metallurgical processing, designed for students with no prior training in this area.

MINE3310.name: Mining Geomechanics
MINE3310.desc: This course aims to provide students with the basic knowledge required to undertake geotechnical investigations.
